Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Turning Vines Into Trees: A Genome Skimming Approach to the Phylogenetics of New World Milkweed VInes (Matelea, subg. Chthamalia, Apocynaceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Although plant adaptations to aridity have been well studied in a few groups, such as cacti, relatively little is known about the diversification of most plants in deserts and other drylands. A group of milkweeds (Matelea subg. Chthamalia) inhabits dry or seasonally dry habitats in Mexico and the southwestern United States, providing a useful system for investigating adaptive diversification in arid bioregions. This group is part of a large, mostly tropical clade of milkweed vines (Gonolobinae) and most exhibit apparent adaptations to aridity. Many have lost their ability to twine (with stems spreading flat on the ground), have small, bell-shaped flowers, or are covered by an abundance of hairs. This research will use the most powerful available techniques to reconstruct the evolutionary history of Chthamalia and to analyze the evolution of adaptations to aridity. Next generation DNA sequencing employing a ?genome skimming? approach will be used to obtain complete chloroplast genomes, partial mitochondrial genomes, and complete nuclear ribosomal gene sequences to robustly estimate phylogenetic relationships, which will serve as a framework for evolutionary analyses of morphological adaptations.

This project will resolve the classification of little-known plants that have been taxonomically controversial. Several species of Chthamalia are exceedingly rare; resolving taxonomic questions and greater knowledge of their evolution will contribute to future conservation efforts of species and habitats. Integration of traditional systematic approaches with new molecular methods is critical to address hypotheses about evolution, adaptation, and speciation. Graduate and undergraduate students will gain laboratory and bioinformatic training as well as the opportunity to present research results at national meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award enabled the collection and analysis of genomic scale data to enhance co-PI Angela McDonnell’s dissertation, “Phylogeny and Evolution of New World Milkweed Vines (Apocynaceae, Gonolobinae) with an Emphasis on the Nontwining Species of Matelea subgenus Chthamalia”. Few studies have addressed evolutionary hypotheses in this large (~450 spp.) group, because of a lack of understanding of species relationships and generic taxonomy. One important group of these vines, Matelea subgenus Chthamalia, is especially interesting because it contains approximately 20 species from the southern US and northern Mexico that vary in hairiness, ability to vine, and flower shape. These are traits associated with adaptation to aridity.  We sought (1) to develop an evolutionary foundation for classifying the species and genera of the milkweed vine subtribe Gonolobinae, (2) to determine relationships among the species of Matelea subgenus Chthamalia, and (3) to analyze patterns of evolution in traits thought to represent adaptations to aridity in these vines.

As a result of funding, 768 low copy nuclear genes, chloroplast genomes, and other high-copy genomic regions were successfully sequenced from 150 samples, representing about 100 species of milkweeds. Our results have illuminated the phylogenetic relationships among lineages of Gonolobinae and will be useful for future systematic and taxonomic studies. Our major findings are that: (1) the largest genus (Matelea) is not a single evolutionary lineage and reclassification of much of the subtribe is warranted and underway; (2) Matelea subgenus Chthamalia is confirmed to be a lineage of approximately 20 species that will be reclassified as a genus in future monographic work, including description of at least one new species; and (3) a loss of twining growth form in Gonolobinae occurred once and was followed by one reversal back to vines within subgenus Chthamalia. The loss of twining followed by a reversal back to twining has not been found elsewhere within Apocynaceae, suggesting a novel morphological transition in Gonolobinae.  Future work will explore whether these changes were associated with changing climate and the development of dry grasslands and deserts in North America.

The synergistic nature of this research enabled co-PI McDonnell to receive  broad training in plant systematics, genomics and evolutionary biology, including skills in using modern molecular and bioinformatics tools along with more traditional morphological data analysis. Through this project, we collaborated with scientists at two Mexican institutions for to conduct field work and specimen collection. One graduate student and three undergraduate students received training in emerging laboratory techniques associated with next generation DNA sequencing as well as assembly and analysis of genome-scale data sets. Results from this research have been published in one article to date; three more publications are in preparation. Findings from our research have been presented five times at regional and national meetings to date. Final results will be presented in 2017.
